Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Recrystallization of Stable Iron Oxides in Reducing Environments
Award.AbstractNarration:
Iron (Fe) oxides are abundant in soils, sediments, and rocks. Like most minerals, Fe oxide minerals undergo transformation reactions as their surroundings change. These transformations can result in the incorporation or release of toxic trace elements, metals, and biological nutrients, which affect water quality. The transformations may also alter an oxide's isotopic composition, which is often used to reconstruct past environmental conditions on Earth. The proposed work will investigate a recently identified, insufficiently characterized Fe oxide transformation reaction: "stable Fe oxide recrystallization". This process involves a solid Fe oxide mineral that undergoes elemental and isotopic exchange with dissolved ions in solution under reducing conditions, which surprisingly has been shown to occur without any obvious changes in the oxide's structure, texture, or particle size. The goal of the proposed work is to determine how and under what conditions stable Fe oxide recrystallization occurs for two common Fe oxide minerals: goethite and magnetite. The outcomes of this project could fundamentally change our understanding of Fe oxide mineral reactions with important implications for earth surficial processes on both modern and ancient Earth.

To study this process, this interdisciplinary team will combine radioactive isotope tracer experiments with spectroscopic, high-resolution microscopic, and pore-scale analyses. This approach will allow us to track recrystallization rates, extents, and spatial distributions for several natural and synthetic Fe oxides with different particle sizes, trace element contents, and recrystallization histories. Achieving our research goal would lead to: (i) more effective groundwater remediation strategies by improving knowledge of how Fe oxides interact with toxic trace metals and radionuclides under a range of geochemical conditions; (ii) improved assessments of past environmental conditions on Earth by examining how Fe oxide isotopic signatures change over time; and (iii) insights into similar, poorly understood recrystallization processes observed for other minerals. In addition to disseminating results through the incorporation of this research into coursework and peer-reviewed publications, this project will support the implementation of an annual week-long summer camp program for grade 6-8 students - "Science Unearthed: The Dirty Details" - which will provide educational opportunities for children, STEM focused undergraduates, and K-12 teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Iron (Fe) oxides in subsurface environments provide reactive surfaces for pollutant uptake and transformation and act as an electron source or storage for Fe(II)-Fe(III) electron transfer reactions.  One class of the more thermodynamically stable Fe(III) oxides (goethite and hematite) were originally thought to participate in these sorption and electron transfer reactions while remaining minimally unchanged physically or chemically.  However, recent developments revealed these Fe(III) oxides, when present in water with dissolved Fe(II), may undergo a significant structural and chemical rearrangement that involves an Fe atom mixing between the solid Fe(III) oxide and dissolved Fe(II) as well as an O atom mixing between the oxide and water, despite little obvious changes in crystal size, morphology, or chemistry.  The goal of this project is to determine how trace metal impurities, which mimic more natural, complex subsurface conditions, influence this redox-driven Fe and O atom exchange process.  To this end, laboratory experiments with Fe and O isotope tracers followed the movement of Fe and O between the Fe oxide and solution under varying geochemical conditions.

Groundwater geochemistry is often a complex mixture of inorganic solutes including trace metals, and these metals can influence Fe oxide reactivity.  Experiments were conducted to evaluate how dissolved trace metals Ni, Co, and Mn influence the exchange of Fe between the oxides and dissolved Fe(II).  Without these trace metals, approximately 10% of Fe(III) in the Fe(III) oxides exchanges with dissolved Fe(II).  The presence of dissolved trace metals causes less Fe(II) sorption and less Fe atom exchange.  The likely reaction mechanism involves the trace metal sorbing onto surface sites and blocking the sorption of Fe(II) and/or the release of new structural Fe(II).    The results suggest that Fe oxides in natural environments with chemical impurities may undergo less Fe atom exchange compared to pure water conditions. 

The influence of Ni, Co, and Mn dopants within the Fe oxide structure (typical for natural oxides) on the Fe atom exchange process as well as the Fe dissolution process was also investigated.  The presence of trace metal dopants within goethite and hematite had little effect on Fe atom exchange rates and extents when the trace metals were at low concentrations (<2% by mass).  However larger (up to 10%) doped concentrations resulted in significantly greater Fe atom exchange activity.  Furthermore, higher amounts of trace metal dopants also resulted in faster and farther Fe dissolution induced by acid, by organic ligands, or by organic reductants and ligands.  Of all physical-chemical factors of the oxides probed to explain this trend, the increase of surface hydroxyl sites, which serve as sites for chemical sorption or structural Fe release, with increasing trace metal dopants was identified as the likely cause for this increased reactivity.  The results suggest more natural Fe oxides with impurities may exchange more Fe due to structural defects compared to pure Fe oxide phases.  Oddly, this enhanced reactivity conflicts with the suppression caused by aqueous trace metals, and which process holds the greater influence in nature requires further exploration. 

The final part of this project sought to provide direct spectroscopic evidence for refining our mathematical models that describe Fe atom exchange.  To date, the Fe exchange process is quantified by a simple mixing model that assumes mixed Fe homogenously arranges itself among the dissolved phase and a portion of the Fe oxide crystal.  Fe and O isotope tracing experiments were conducted to quantify the fraction of Fe atom exchange, and nanoscale secondary ion mass spectrometry was used to directly measure the Fe isotope abundances at the surfaces of goethite and hematite.  These surface measurements revealed that the dissolved Fe(II) incorporation into the oxide surface was greater than what the fraction of Fe exchange model predicts.  The depth of Fe and O atom exchange was also probed using larger crystals obtained from natural settings, and Fe was found to exchange a few microns into the oxide structure in a non-linear distribution that cannot be explained by simple diffusion.  Therefore, the assumption of homogenous mixing of a portion of the oxide is no longer correct, and a new heterogeneous mixing model is in development to explain these results. 

This project provided research opportunities for two graduate students and one undergraduate student.  Students received training in diverse topics of environmental engineering including iron mineralogy and crystallography, mass spectrometry, environmental analytical chemistry, and water quality analysis.  One Masters thesis was produced, and one PhD dissertation and three publications are in preparation.  Research results were incorporated into the PI’s graduate courses in environmental chemistry and environmental engineering unit operations.  The project results are expected to bridge the knowledge gap between pure laboratory systems and more natural conditions when explaining Fe oxide reactivity.  Fundamental information on trace metal behavior with Fe oxides was also acquired.  The results should also be helpful in understanding the behavior of trace metals in subsurface environments.
